title: Anzügliche Grafik sorgt für Spott
cleaned_sentences: Russia's TV propaganda: Supervious graphics ensure mockery and malice Russia's state broadcaster Russia-1 wanted to report on the border closures of Finland.
But an embarrassing breakdown in the representation now provides ridicule and malice.
Moscow - Russian state television represents the last route between St. Petersburg in Russia and Helsinki, the capital of Finland, by a graphic.
Until further notice, only one transition remains open.
It is only embarrassing that the graphic is strongly reminiscent of a male genital organ.

Russia's state TV shows explicit graphics on the border situation in Finland Evgeny Popov, member of Wladimir Putin's "United Russia" party and moderator in the Russian state TV, caused a stir with a report on the border situation in Finland.
He and his wife Olga Skabejewa, both well -known propagandists, also moderate the program "60 minutes".
The format is known for the spread of misinformation on the Ukraine War.
Anton Gerashchenko, advisor to the Ukrainian Ministry of the Interior, published an 18 -second section of the show on X (formerly Twitter).
Popov can be seen on how he faces the suggestive representation of the remaining border crossing and explains the border situation in Finland.
The authenticity of the presentation cannot be confirmed independently.
The reactions of other X-users were not long in coming and a wave of ridicule broke out through the presentation.
For example, users commented on: "Russian TV presents the penis route."

Finland complains of migration pressure on the border with Russia In the past few weeks, more than 700 migrants from different countries have come across the Russian-Finnish border, whereupon Finland concluded almost all border crossings to Russia.
Finland blames the Russian government to have triggered the migration movements.
"Unfortunately, there are many signs that Russian border officials and possibly other authorities are involved," said a spokesman for the Finnish Ministry of the Interior to Reuters.
He described the continuing migration pressure on the border as the "hybrid attack surgery" of Russia.

Sari Arho, member of the Rusi Thinktank and guest researcher at the University of Helsinki, said in an interview with Newsweek that the "attack operation" of Russia could be a reaction to the NATO accession of Finland and the "Defense Cooperation Agreement with the USA".
According to Arho, Finland is ready to "react to the Russian pressure attempts", but the situation "is not easier, but could worsen."
